title: LetDirective
contents:
mode_edit code
API > @ngrx/component

LetDirectivelink

The *ngrxLet directive serves a convenient way of binding observables to a view context (DOM element's scope). It also helps with several internal processing under the hood.

Selectorslink

  • [ngrxLet]

Propertieslink

Property Description
@Input()
ngrxLet: PO 		Write-only.
@Input('ngrxLetSuspenseTpl')
suspenseTemplateRef?: TemplateRef<unknown>

Descriptionlink

Displaying Observable Valueslink

<ng-container *ngrxLet="number$ as n"> <app-number [number]="n"></app-number> </ng-container> <ng-container *ngrxLet="number$; let n"> <app-number [number]="n"></app-number> </ng-container>

Tracking Different Observable Eventslink

<ng-container *ngrxLet="number$ as n; error as e; complete as c"> <app-number [number]="n" *ngIf="!e && !c"> </app-number> <p *ngIf="e">There is an error: {{ e }}</p> <p *ngIf="c">Observable is completed.</p> </ng-container>

Combining Multiple Observableslink

<ng-container *ngrxLet="{ users: users$, query: query$ } as vm"> <app-search-bar [query]="vm.query"></app-search-bar> <app-user-list [users]="vm.users"></app-user-list> </ng-container>

Using Suspense Templatelink

<ng-container *ngrxLet="number$ as n; suspenseTpl: loading"> <app-number [number]="n"></app-number> </ng-container> <ng-template #loading> <p>Loading...</p> </ng-template>

Using Aliases for Non-Observable Valueslink

<ng-container *ngrxLet="userForm.controls.email as email"> <input type="text" [formControl]="email" /> <ng-container *ngIf="email.errors && (email.touched || email.dirty)"> <p *ngIf="email.errors.required">This field is required.</p> <p *ngIf="email.errors.email">This field must be an email.</p> </ng-container> </ng-container>
